abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as highly
            satisfactory and project sustainability is highly likely.
            Both World Bank and Borrower performances were adjudged
            highly satisfactory. Accumulating experience and lessons
            learned was a main goal of this LIL-financed project.
            Policy-level lessons learned were that: Microprojects can
            simultaneously create short-term jobs and improve
            infrastructure and facilities that are critical to
            preserving Bulgaria's human resources and expanding
            private sector employment and growth. Microprojects can
            contribute to Bulgaria's broader efforts to
            decentralize the provision of public goods and services to
            local governments in a way that also helps local governments
            fight poverty. The RIF Steering Committee composition and
            its operation raised some questions of bias and political
            favortism and will need to be more open and transparent. The
            challenge is to maximize the impact of the RIF's
            investments by using its leverage to attract other sources
            of funding. Some lessons learned from RIF management and
            operations were: Keep bureacracy at a minimum. Microprojects
            should be aligned with existing Bulgarian legislation and
            regulations. The Steering Committee would beenfit from
            greater transparency and input from more diverse partners.
            Local capacity to conduct social analysis, community
            organizing, and social impact evaluations will need to be
            strengthened. The schedule and deadlines for processing
            microproject applications should be more flexible.
            "Exclusive" and

5086003.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Regional Initiatives Fund Project
            (RIF) for Bulgaria aims to test the social fund mechanism as
            a means of improving the standards of living among the poor
            and unemployed during the economic transition. The project
            has three components. The Microprojects component finances
            about 100 microprojects identified and prepared by
            municipalities, nongovernmental organizations, and other
            intermediaries. The majority of microprojects would include
            civil works to improve water supply, sanitation, solid waste
            management, soil recovery, rehabilitation of local health
            units, schools, feeder roads, and irrigation works. The
            second component, Labor Market Analysis, includes two labor
            force surveys, a net impact evaluation of active labor
            market programs (Lamps), and investigation of legal and
            administrative changes conducive to microcredit. The third
            component, Project Management, includes operating costs
            costs, training, and technical assistance as well as
            monitoring and evaluation of microprojects and work by the
            Project Management unit to design and develop the RIF on
            behalf of the government.
